pages.teaser: FORMER X Factor judge Dannii Minogue and Kris Smith have separated
pages.articlebody:
DEVASTATED Dannii Minogue has split from the dad of her little son after months of blazing rows.

The break-up of the former X Factor judge, 40, and model Kris Smith, 33, comes 20 months after the birth of toddler Ethan.

The pair finally broke up after a series of bust-ups spanning nearly a year, and a trial separation.

A friend of Dannii said: “She is utterly distraught that her dreams have come crashing down around her.”

Dannii and Kris, a former rugby league star who has played for Halifax and Leeds, were together for four years.

The pal added: “They used to talk about marriage and the future but recently it was all just bad vibes and blazing rows.

“Dannii fought really hard to keep the family together for the sake of Ethan but her efforts haven’t worked.”

Aussie DANNII, who is recovering from a thyroid condition, moved back to Melbourne from her adopted home of London to set up a family base Down Under. She is now a judge on Australia’s Got Talent.

Brit KRIS is a model for leading Aussie department store chain Myer and has also become a sought-after TV personality in Oz. The friend said Dannii is “upset and angry” at putting her career on the back burner to support his rise.

The pal added: “Dannii had to turn down X Factor because she wanted to build the family in Oz, where Kris was starting to get noticed. “He gave her all this rubbish about her being ‘the one’.”

There is no suggestion of cheating on either side. But Kris set tongues wagging last year when he was pictured flirting with Australia’s ex-Miss Universe Jennifer Hawkins.

pages.headline: Child sex offence every 20mins
pages.teaser: MORE than 400 children are sexually abused every week in UK — as figures show 9 out of 10 paedos go unpunished
pages.articlebody:
MORE than 400 children are sexually abused every week in Britain — one every 20 MINUTES, a shock investigation has revealed.

The NSPCC called for urgent action as figures showed nine out of ten paedophiles go unpunished.

A child abuse expert last night said Britain has a massive paedophile problem — which should be treated like an outbreak of DISEASE.

Jon Brown urged the Government to act as shocking figures obtained by the NSPCC showed perverts are lurking the length and breadth of the country.

The 43 police forces in England and Wales recorded 23,097 child sex offences last year. That included rape, incest, child prostitution and pornography.

The annual figure is equivalent to 444 attacks a week — or one kiddie abused every 20 minutes.

Just as worryingly, only 2,135 of offences reported — ten per cent — led to someone actually being convicted and sentenced. Thousands of paedos escape scot-free.

Mr Brown, head of the NSPCC’s Sexual Abuse programme, said: “When you have a situation where more than 60 children are being sexually abused every day, something is very wrong.

“The Government has to start treating the situation as seriously as they would if faced with an outbreak of chronic disease.

“We also need a clearer picture of what is happening between an offence being reported and someone appearing in court. The police are doing their best to bring prosecutions but we need to understand why there is such a huge disparity between the figures. The fact there are repeat offences against some children also shows not all are one-off incidents.”

London’s Metropolitan Police dealt with the most abuse cases, a total of 3,420. The Leveson Inquiry into Press standards has heard Scotland Yard has 150 cops working on its phone hacking investigation — and just 27 devoted to nailing paedophiles.

London’s Deputy Mayor Kit Malthouse also told the inquiry the Met’s bill for probing phone hacking is forecast to hit £40million.

In contrast, £36million is spent annually on investigating child abuse in the capital.

Thames Valley Police, covering Oxfordshire, Buckinghamshire and Berkshire, had the second highest child abuse figures, with 1,264 offences. Last month the force smashed an alleged child sex ring in the university city of Oxford. It is claimed 24 victims — some as young as 11 — were groomed, drugged and raped over a period of six years.

Six men aged 26 to 37 are remanded in custody awaiting trial.

A former officer with Thames Valley Police was jailed for 18 years in January for a campaign of sex abuse described by a judge as “one of the most despicable cases” he had heard.

Mohammed Younas, 43, of High Wycombe, Bucks, was convicted by a jury of 15 counts of rape of a girl over the course of eight years, from when she was seven years old.

Aylesbury Crown Court heard Younas, whose father was a colonel in the Pakistani Army, would rape his victim every other day at the height of the abuse.

In another case involving Thames Valley, pervert David Cox was jailed for two years in February for breaching a Sexual Offences Prevention Order. He was being monitored by the force after being banned from unsupervised contact with children by a court in Sussex.

But he attended services at St Ebbe’s Church, Oxford, where he mingled with children, including a vulnerable young girl.

He was only caught when a support worker at the hostel where he was living caught him downloading extreme pornography.

West Yorks was third in the police figures of child abuse cases, with 1,170 allegations. It was followed by Hampshire, which had 1,148.

More than 1,470 of the national total were aged five and under, 4,973 were ten to five and 14,819 were between 11 and 17. Six times as many girls (19,790) were abused as boys (3,218), the NSPCC said.

The figures released yesterday show a small drop from 2010, when a total 23,390 offences were recorded.

But the NSPCC’s Mr Brown said: “A concentrated effort has to be made if we are to start reducing this distressing level of offences, many of which are committed on extremely young and helpless children.

“The NSPCC is doing what it can by using information like this from the police to tailor our treatment services. We are also pioneering new programmes, including our Schools Service, which aims to work with 1.8million kids aged seven to 11 over the next four years.

“But we can’t tackle this problem by ourselves.

“It requires a major effort from government and the public to give children the protection they need and to provide more therapeutic programmes — so the young victims of abuse can start to rebuild their lives.”

208 children saved by

Sarah’s Law in its first year

By GRAEME WILSON, Deputy Political Editor

SARAH’S Law has protected more than 200 kids from predatory paedophiles and criminals in its first year, Theresa May will reveal today.

Cops have had more than 1,600 enquiries from parents wanting to check on an adult with access to their children.

Their investigations turned up at least 160 paedophiles — plus a further 58 who had committed other offences.

The news was welcomed last night by Sara Payne, whose eight-year-old daughter Sarah was murdered by paedophile Roy Whiting in 2000.

She said the law, named after her daughter, was a vital weapon against child abusers.

It allows parents to ask cops to check the background of new partners or other adults with access to their children.

Ms Payne said last night: “If just one child had been kept safe as a result of Sarah’s Law then all the work to see it introduced would have been worth it.

“The fact that it is hundreds of children is wonderful and testament to the fact the scheme is needed.

“It sends out a message to convicted sex offenders that they cannot hide their criminal history.”

Michelle Skeer, the Assistant Chief Constable of Cumbria, also praised the legislation.

She said it had helped protect children and ensured greater public confidence in the police and “other responsible authorities” in the monitoring of child sex offenders.

Mrs May will say today: “Thanks to Sarah’s Law, we know that more than 200 children have been protected from potential harm over the last year.

“We’re doing everything we can to protect the public, and especially children, from predatory sex offenders by tightening the law and closing loopholes.”

pages.headline: George's ex: We never divorced
pages.teaser: THIRD wife of newlywed MP angry as he unveils bride No4 — & says they’re still married
pages.byline: By NEIL SYSON and CHRIS POLLARD
pages.articlebody:
THE third wife of newlywed MP George Galloway reacted angrily last night as he unveiled bride No4 — and said: “We never divorced.”

Rima Husseini, cradling the Respect Party leader’s four-month-old son, accused the politician of using outdated Muslim relationship rules as he wooed Putri Gayatri Pertiwi, 30 years his junior.

Rima, who married 57-year-old Galloway in 2007 and also bore him a four-year-old boy, said he had done nothing illegal, but insisted he was behind the times.

She said: “We married under Islamic law. There’s a misconception you can have up to four wives in Islam, but it’s not true.

“It may have been hundreds and hundreds of years ago, when men were going to war and being killed — but it doesn’t exist now.

“Under Islamic law we remain married.

“He hasn’t done anything illegal, but morally it’s a different story.

“I’m asking for a divorce, but he’s been refusing for months. To this day he refuses to grant me a divorce.”

Galloway wed Dutch-born consultant Putri, 27, last Saturday, less than two days after he took Labour’s Bradford West stronghold with a by-election win. The politician yesterday posed happily with Putri — two years younger than his oldest child — at his South London home.

He said with a wink that he’d been awake to 2.45am, calling himself “indefatigable” — an apparent reference to his controversial description of Iraqi despot Saddam Hussein in 1994.

The Scot — dubbed “Gorgeous George” — then revealed he’d been up until that time selecting council election candidates.

Claiming he was interested only in talking about his new role in Parliament, he added: “Why would I discuss my personal life?”

Galloway, born in a Dundee slum, was with first wife Elaine from 1979 to 1987. They had two kids.

In 1994 he married Palestinian scientist Dr Amineh Abu-Zayyad in a Muslim ceremony, before wedding Lebanese Rima, now 41.

In 2006, he was ridiculed for donning a catsuit and pretending to lick milk on TV’s Big Brother.

A spokesman said last night: “Mr Galloway won’t engage in a war of words with the mother of two of his children. He was free to marry last Saturday and he did.”

pages.subdeck: ETI-MAD ... Utd hero Rooney hopes to clinch Prem title at City's Etihad stadium
pages.headline: Let's win title at City
pages.teaser: UTD striker hopes the Premier League leaders can win crown at their neighbours’ home
pages.articlebody:
WAYNE ROONEY dreams of winning the Premier League in Manchester City’s backyard.

Manchester United have opened up a five-point lead over their rivals with seven games to go.

And if the two clubs mirror each other’s results over the next four matches, United could retain their crown in the derby at the Etihad on April 30.

That would be the perfect scenario for the Red Devils, who are still haunted by their 6-1 humiliation at Old Trafford in October.

Striker Rooney admitted: “We’re certainly good enough to beat them there. We showed that when we beat them 3-2 in the FA Cup in January.

“They have a great home record in the league but we managed to get the result there in the Cup.

“That shows we can go there and win. We just have to be ourselves and play our normal football.

“We’ll take full confidence into that game and hopefully we can get the three points.

“We’ll approach it as we do any normal game.

“There are three points up for grabs and we’ll be trying to get them. We won’t be doing anything different.”

The Premier League say there is no chance of United being presented with the trophy at the home of their neighbours.

But that will not stop United from trying to inflict a major blow over City by sealing it in front of a packed Etihad.

Boss Alex Ferguson has targeted four wins before then to really turn up the heat on Roberto Mancini’s men.

He said: “We play several games before we get there. Hopefully we can navigate those games and win them and see where that takes us.

“It was always going to be a massive game.”

Rooney has set his sights on beating Bobby Charlton’s goalscoring record for United.

Roo has 28 goals for the current campaign, taking him to 175 goals in his Red Devils career.

That tally leaves him just four adrift of Dennis Viollet and George Best, who are joint fourth.

And Rooney, 26, regards Charlton’s mark of 249 as the ultimate target.

He told Inside United: “Of course, it would be an unbelievable feeling if I could get his record.

“I’m still a long way away but hopefully, one day, I’ll be able to do it.

“Viollet and Best are club legends and to be in touching distance of their goal tally is something I’m really proud of. Hopefully I’ll overtake them soon.”

pages.subdeck: Arrested ... Cedric Brown
pages.headline: UK's Most Wanted held in carjacked vehicle with kids inside
pages.teaser: WEST Midlands Police say they have detained Cedric Brown after 'violent struggle'
pages.articlebody:
ONE of Britain’s most wanted men has been arrested in a carjacked vehicle containing two TODDLERS.

Cedric Brown, 44, was detained after a "violent struggle" near the scene of a suspected burglary in Erdington, Birmingham.

West Midlands Police said officers “flooded” the area surrounding Slade Road in Erdington shortly before 11am yesterday following reports that a burglary was under way.

A force spokesman said the mother of the two children, a one-year-old boy and a two-year-old girl, was dragged from her Ford Focus, which was then cornered by police around a mile away.

Sergeant Nicholas Barnes said: “Several police vehicles were in pursuit and the man abandoned the Ford Focus in South Grove where he was arrested by officers who then spotted the toddlers.

“Thankfully, neither of them was hurt and we quickly reunited them with their mum, who naturally was extremely relieved.

“Officers responded to calls of the burglary within minutes. The suspects simply didn’t have enough time to get away from the location before they were swamped by police.”

Detectives are now quizzing Brown — nicknamed 'Skipper' — on suspicion of robbery and burglary.

Brown was wanted over a brutal stabbing and burglary at a farmhouse near Bristol in November 2010.

The 49-year-old victim was slashed in the stomach with a kitchen knife and suffered cuts to his head and face as his wife was forced to watch.

The horrific incident was featured on the BBC’s Crimewatch programme.

Police suspect Brown has been in the West Midlands for some time as detectives hunted for him in the Bristol area.

He is suspected of being among two intruders who fled after demanding money at the couple’s home in Goose Green, near Warmley.

Police previously scrambled a Western Counties police helicopter in a bid to catch him after the attack.

Detective Inspector Jill Kells, of Avon and Somerset police, said at the time: “This was a very serious assault and it’s important we find the men responsible quickly.

“It was obviously terrifying for the victims.”

Two other men, aged 18 and 19, from Birmingham, were arrested in an alleyway near the scene of yesterday's incident and are being questioned over the Slade Road burglary.

pages.headline: Wintry weather leaves 50,000 homes without power
pages.teaser: NEARLY 50,000 homes and businesses have been left without power today after heavy snow and gales
pages.articlebody:
NEARLY 50,000 homes and businesses have been left without power today as HEAVY SNOW and GALES brought chaos to the north of England.

Emergency workers leapt into action as outages hit 40,000 homes in Yorkshire and the North East.

Another 9,000 were affected in Derbyshire and thousands were experiencing supply problems in the Peak District.

The deluge of snow, sleet and rain was expected to continue throughout the day and move further south.

Heavy winds that hit nearly 70mph last night are also set to return — just days after experts declared March the warmest for 55 years.

Snow ploughs were this morning attempting to clear blocked roads as locals in North East England struggled with drifts up to 7ft high.

The crew of a stricken cargo vessel was winched to safety after it grounded on the Welsh coast near Colwyn Bay in Gale Force Nine winds last night.

The Met Office has issued severe yellow weather warnings for snow and ice in parts of Wales, northern England, the Midlands and Scotland.

Up to 8in of snow fell in the Peak District, Pennines, West Northumberland, North Yorkshire and Cumbria overnight, while trees were felled on higher ground.

County Durham was particularly badly hit and police there urged people to be “good neighbours”.

Chief Superintendent Andy Reddick said: “If you have an elderly or vulnerable person living near you, please check that they are OK and help them wrap up warm.”

As many as 40 vehicles were stuck on the A68 between Tow Law and Castleside this morning amid reports of drifts 7ft deep.

Two families were given shelter overnight in Durham's Barnard Castle Police Station after becoming stranded on the A66 while some flights from Leeds Bradford Airport were delayed by up to two hours.

Forecaster Aisling Creevy said a band of rain, sleet and snow would move be moving south today.

She said: “There is currently a band of rain sleet and snow across northern Wales, the north west Midlands and northern England which will generally move southwards throughout the day leaving very cold and icy conditions behind it.

“There will also be very strong winds again today after gusts of 66mph were recorded in Warcop in Cumbria overnight.”

Power cuts began to hit the Northumberland area yesterday afternoon as overhead cables were blown down.

Cumbria Police said the A66 Trans Pennine route remains closed in both directions and the A537 in Cheshire was badly hit by snow this morning.

The A57 Snake Pass linking Sheffield and Manchester was also closed.

Around 80,000 properties in the North East and Yorkshire suffered power cuts overnight.

Engineers worked round the clock to restore power to 50 per cent of them by 8am, Northern Powergrid said.

A spokesman said: “All available engineering teams have been deployed and are working hard to restore power to customers as soon as possible.”

It came after 11,000 Scottish Hydro customers were also left without power yesterday morning.

Conditions are expected to remain wintry tonight. In the North temperatures could drop as low as -5C overnight.

London and the South are not expected to get above 12C today with highs of 7C elsewhere.

The Met Office said: “Rain is expected to turn to snow on high ground as colder air moves south across England and Wales during today.

“Some 2-5cm of snow is likely in places, mainly above around 200m with as much as 10 to 15cm possible above 300m.

“Little, if any, snow is expected to accumulate on roads and pavements below 200m. The area of rain, sleet and snow will clear from the north during the day.”

Mario's girlfriend, model Raffaella Fico, recently said she didn't mind him going to strip clubs as long as he behaved.

pages.headline: Hunt for Sussex pet poisoner
pages.teaser: SADISTIC nut has left food laced with rat killing pellets on footpaths along coast
pages.byline: By ANTONELLA LAZZERI on trail of dog poisoner
pages.articlebody:
THIS is one of the beaches where a dog hater is trying to kill pets with poisoned sandwiches.

The Sun went to investigate after the sadistic nut left food laced with rat killing pellets on footpaths along a stretch of coast.

One dog has already died and four have suffered serious illness around Chichester, West Sussex.

Judith Peeters’ pet Rusty was the first known victim.

She rushed the 12-year-old rescue dog to the vet’s after spotting blue-green pellets in a sarnie the dog had stopped to eat at Bosham in January.

Judith said: “I was horrified. I knew instantly what the pellets were as I’d seen rat poison before. We took Rusty to the vet’s where she was given something to make her sick.

“If I hadn’t realised she’d have died a slow, agonising death as the poison kills by making you bleed internally.

“I can’t believe a sane person would leave poison on a footpath. I’ve heard at least five dogs have been poisoned.”

She said a child could easily become a victim — attracted by the brightly-coloured rat poison pellets.

Judith told everyone she knew in Bosham of the poisoned food, including pal Helen Weston whose Italian Spinone dog Rufus ate some on a walk a few weeks later.

Helen, 60, said: “I saw him snaffle something. At home he suddenly had a fit. Thank God Judith had warned me.”

Helen, whose dog faced a two-day fight for life, added: “Someone who doesn’t like the fact irresponsible dog owners don’t clear up after their pets must be behind all this.”

Council dog wardens are looking out for poisoned food and notices have gone up reading: “Warning: Dogs and animals are being poisoned in this area. Please be aware.”

The latest poisoning was at East Wittering where thousands will spend Easter.

Rosalind Matthews, 68, who was walking her two dogs there, said: “It’s very worrying. You’d have to be a madman to plant poison sandwiches.”

Teacher Nikki Day, 43, who walks her dog Merlin on the beach, said: “I just can’t believe someone could be that evil.”

Police are probing at least three dog poisoning cases — one involving the death of an English Bull Terrier after a walk in Sidlesham in March.

pages.headline: Boy,14, posted porn film of him with girl on Facebook
pages.teaser: LAD arrested over video of himself and 14-year-old girl which was shared online
pages.articlebody:
A 14-YEAR-OLD boy has been arrested after a porn film featuring him and a girl of the same age was posted on Facebook.

The video was also shared among pupils at school and there are fears it has already been seen by thousands of youngsters nationwide.

The teen, from Cheltenham, was given a final warning by police which will remain on his file for six years.

Headteacher Lawrence Montagu wrote to parents of pupils at St Peter's High School in Gloucester to warn them — though neither teen was a pupil there.

He said: "I am led to believe that this video involves young people from schools in Gloucestershire but not, I emphasise, St Peter's.

"However, I know that the video has been viewed by students in St Peter's and I have spoken to the school about the lack of dignity and self-respect people have who allow themselves to be portrayed in such a way.”

Gloucestershire Constabulary said the force had spoken to the girl and her parents.

Growing problem

Inspector Andy Matheson said such incidents were a growing national problem.

He said: "The practice of posting compromising or even pornographic pictures on the internet is something that is happening with increasing frequency nationally. The current proliferation of smart phones enables images to be taken and shared with ease.

"What a lot of people don't realise is that as soon as they share a photograph with someone else, whether by MMS or by posting it on a social networking site, they lose control of that image, and while the image can be deleted, it could easily have been copied by any number of people in the meantime.

"A very common practice among young people at the moment is 'sexting' – the act of sending sexually explicit photographs, primarily between mobile phones. If the subject of the image is under 18 then anyone who makes, possesses or shares the image commits a criminal offence.

"The consequences can be quite devastating for the person concerned.”

Mr Montagu told This Is Gloucestershire that modern technology was to blame.

He said: "It is very sad that our young people are exposed to such pornography, but it is one of the evils of modern technology.

"We simply have to continue educating the young to reap the benefits that modern technology offers but not to fall into the trap of misusing it.

"We must try to persuade them that we should not want to be involved in listening to or looking at anything that portrays a lack of dignity and respect for other people."

pages.teaser: TV bosses have hit upon the perfect formula for an advert – blonde bombshell Kate Upton in a bikini and just seven words of dialogue
pages.articlebody:
TV bosses have hit upon the formula for the perfect advert — blonde bombshell Kate Upton in a bikini and just seven words of dialogue.

Chiefs from America’s DirectTV have ditched any clever gimmicks or sales patter — instead opting to just film the gorgeous 19-year-old in a blue floral bikini on the beach.

THE moment that Wills and Kate announced their engagement to the world has been immortalised — as the royal couple have finally been made into waxworks.

The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge joined a long line of royals at Madame Tussauds today — and staff believe that they will be even more popular than the Queen.

And the models — which took four months to complete and cost £150,00 each — look freakishly similar to the real thing.

Set in a pose and setting taken from the day of their engagement announcement at St James’s Palace, Prince William stands with his hands clasped in front of him and Kate, in her now famous blue Issa dress, smiles broadly next to him.

Kate sports a replica of the sapphire and diamond engagement ring once worn by Princess Diana, while Wills is clad in a navy suit.

Visitors to the famous London attraction have continually been asking for the royal couple to be added to the exhibits since news of the betrothal was released in autumn 2010.

Liz Edwards, from Madame Tussauds, said: “The Queen is the most popular attraction but since the royal wedding fever we’ve had people coming in to see William when he was without Catherine.

“Catherine has her own star quality so we are expecting a lot of people to come, especially with the Easter weekend coming.”

pages.headline: Tornadoes rip through Texas
pages.teaser: SEVERAL powerful tornadoes have touched down near Dallas destroying homes, flipping lorries into the air and uprooting trees
pages.articlebody:
SEVERAL powerful tornadoes touched down near Dallas last night — destroying hundreds of homes, flipping trucks into the air and uprooting trees.

Between six to 12 twisters swept through North Texas leaving 17 injured — but no reported deaths.

US TV footage showed images of houses with roofs and second storeys missing.

One of the tornadoes touched down in a parking lot full of articulated lorries, and a local television station captured the vehicles FLYING through the air.

Some of the cargo containers attached to the lorries were flattened.

The storms led to hundreds of flights being cancelled — while 110 planes were damaged in a violent HAIL storm.

Passengers were moved away from windows for their safety at Dallas-Fort Worth Airport — the eighth busiest airport in the world.

Some homes were almost completely blown away.

Dallas County spokeswoman Maria Arita said: “Obviously we're going to have a lot of assessments to make when this is done.”

The National Weather Service (NWS) at first reported at least two "large and extremely dangerous" tornadoes.

Later, senior NWS meteorologist Eric Martello said an estimated six to 12 twisters had touched down, although survey teams had yet to confirm the numbers.

Witnesses said the twisters formed quickly.

Local Jonathan Cook said: “All of a sudden, the rain and hail ceased.”

pages.subdeck: War veteran ... William Davis
pages.headline: Woman, 35, held over death of 92-year-old decorated war vet
pages.teaser: A 35-YEAR-OLD woman has been arrested on suspicion of murdering a 92-year-old decorated war veteran who was found dead in his house
pages.articlebody:
A 35-YEAR-OLD woman has been arrested on suspicion of murdering a decorated war veteran.

William Davis, 92, was found collapsed at his home in Willenhall, West Midlands, on Sunday evening.

He died as a result of severe head injuries, West Midlands Police said.

Detectives arrested the local woman last night and said she is helping police with their inquiries.

At a press conference held by the force yesterday, Detective Superintendent Richard Baker described Mr Davis as a fiercely independent decorated war veteran who was a father to two, grandfather to four and a great-grandfather to one.

He said: “Bill used to go into Willenhall on a weekly basis. He tended his own garden and maintained his home on his own. He was very well-known in the local community and used to stop and chat to his neighbours.

“We know he was seen at 9am on Sunday April 1 in his front garden, where he stopped and chatted to passers-by.

“At around 3.15pm a neighbour took some lunch round to his house. At 6pm concerned neighbours who were unable to rouse Bill gained access to his property and found him.”

The house remains sealed off and forensic searches are continuing.

Mr Baker appealed for anyone who might have been in the Fisher Street and Hobley Street area on Sunday to come forward.

He also pointed out that anyone responsible would have left the address heavily blood-stained and appealed for anyone who knows a friend, neighbour or associate who had blood-stained clothing and was either trying to conceal them or wash them to come forward.

Police have asked anyone with any information relating to the incident to contact the force criminal investigation department at force CID by dialling 101 or speak to Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111.

pages.headline: Disability benefit cheat caught on rollercoaster
pages.teaser: MAN caged for sixteen months after visiting theme park while claiming he could barely walk
pages.articlebody:
A BENEFIT cheat who claimed he could barely walk has been jailed — after he was caught riding a rollercoaster at Alton Towers.

Joseph Smith, 41, of Runcorn, Cheshire, said he could only walk eight metres without suffering severe discomfort.

But fraud investigators caught him staying on his feet for long periods at the Staffordshire theme park, as well as enjoying himself on the rides.

He was also filmed lifting bundles of traffic cones while working as a car park marshall under a fake name.

And he was caged for 16 months last week after admitting three fraud charges and falsely claiming £37,167 in benefits.

Judge Nicholas Woodward said: "This money came from allowances society tries to give to the most vulnerable people.

"When offences like this are committed, the people affected are the most vulnerable."

Prosecutor Tom Watson said: “He claimed an inability to walk without severe discomfort. He described his speed as slow and walking as poor.

”He said he required physical support and used a walking stick.”

Watson added: “He spent hours on his feet, bending down to pick up traffic cones, and all this without the use of walking sticks.

"Covert films were also made of a day out at Alton Towers theme park.

"He was capable of walking and staying on his feet for long periods of time. He visited various rides and was using them.”

Gary Lawrenson, defending Smith, who was born with spina bifida, said: “He has expressed his extreme remorse by pleading guilty.

"He does have medical problems, though he accepts he has exaggerated them.”

pages.headline: You're Notts going to believe this... 3rd win in lucky lotto capital
pages.teaser: LUCKIEST UK county bags a third impressive lotto win in less than three months
pages.articlebody:
A COUPLE have scooped a £4.4million jackpot in Britain’s luckiest lotto county.

It’s the third time Nottinghamshire has been the home of a big win in under three months.

Jim Emerton and his wife Maureen, from Carlton, bagged a £4,449,039 prize in Saturday’s Lotto draw.

He reckons players will be flooding over the border to tap into some of their local fortune.

Jim, 56, said: “When we checked the numbers and our ticket again on Sunday morning, we remembered it was April 1, so we thought it was an April Fool’s joke.”

Asked how they felt about living in such a lucky county, Jim said: “It is strange. We were talking about this the other week, the EuroMillions being in England all the time, and we thought that was strange.

“I don’t know if there’s anything going off in Nottinghamshire or whether they know something everybody else doesn’t know, but it’s certainly working.

“Everybody’s going to move to Nottinghamshire now and start buying lottery tickets.”

The couple now plan to buy their first ever home and splash out on a cruise to celebrate their 30th wedding anniversary in June.

Jim added: “We couldn’t have done that before.”

Their win comes after Gareth and Catherine Bull, from Mansfield, banked £40,627,241 on January 20.

Then Cassey Carrington and Matt Topham, both 22, from Stapleford, netted £45,160,170 on February 7.

Jim thought the win was an elaborate April Fool’s joke when his wife checked their ticket the night before April 1.

Maureen, 55, spotted the win first and Jim thought she was playing a prank on him.

He said: “I said to her ’How have you done this?’ Because I thought it was a trick, I thought it was a trick ticket.

“The more she said it, the more I didn’t believe her because she didn’t seem that excited.

“She said it was because she just couldn’t believe it.

“I’m a fool, I like playing tricks on people and I thought ’Someone’s got me back’.”

By the time they thought to ring Camelot it was 11pm and the phone lines were closed so they had to wait until Sunday morning after a restless night's sleep.

The couple won with numbers 2, 5, 18, 40, 47 and 49.

A police spokesman “The man was injured with a bottle.”

pages.headline: Seven sailors saved from stricken ship in rescue mission off Welsh coast
pages.teaser: A DARING rescue operation saved seven crew members from a stricken cargo ship
pages.articlebody:
THE crew of a stricken cargo ship was hauled to safety last night during a daring rescue operation off the Welsh coast.

Seven seamen were winched off the vessel after it a hit a rock and ran aground near a quarry jetty at Llanddulas, near Colwyn Bay, north Wales.

The ship, called Carrier, got into difficulties as the Welsh coast was battered by Gale Force Nine winds and five metre swells.

Five Polish crew members were lifted off the boat by a Royal Navy Sea King rescue helicopter scrambled from RNAS Prestwick.

But the two remaining crew were forced to stay on board after the aircraft developed a problem with its winch wire.

Rescue co-ordinators sent out for a second helicopter from RAF Leconfield, which eventually pulled the men from the ship.

While all the crew were safely rescued, there are now fears that the vessel’s fuel tanks may have been ruptured, which could spark environmental disaster.

The cargo ship was in one piece following the incident but the concern is that it could begin to leak some of the 40,000 litres of fuel it is carrying, said The Marine and Coastguard Agency.

Eyewitness Sophie Madeley, from Llandudno Junction, said the rescue teams had done an "amazing" job.

She said: "I have watched this all night. My high respect goes out to the pilot of the helicopter for the amazing work I watched him do, and also out to the crew for battling it through what has happened."

An operation to refloat the vessel is expected to begin later.

A Welsh Government spokesman said: "The Welsh Government is closely monitoring the emerging situation at Llanddulas.

"We are being kept fully informed of developments."

The RNLI said the vessel hit a rock on the breakwater at Llanddulas and ended up with its broadside on the shore.

It added that the Llandudno and Rhyl all-weather lifeboats launched into a "full gale and rough seas" at 8.30pm and arrived on scene by 9pm.

A Marine and Coastguard Agency spokesman said: "It is not yet clear what the reason was for this ship running aground."

pages.headline: Greece lightning
pages.teaser: ELECTRIFYING image shows snaps of over 70 lightning strikes over Greece stitched together
pages.articlebody:
THIS electrifying shot shows a severe storm as it passes the Greek island of Ikaria.

Photographer Chris Kotsiopoulos stitched together 70 different shots he took as the storm drifted past off the coast of the mainland.

Chris had set up his camera on a tripod to do some night shots when the storm blew in. For the next hour and 20 minutes he snapped away as the lightning raged out to sea.

Chris, from Athens, said: “It was like there was a fire in the sky.

“I set up my camera on a tripod on the island at night to get pictures of the sky and the stars when the storm rolled by off the coast.

“By stitching 70 shots together it gives a picture of the whole storm as it moved past over 83 minutes.

“In order to make the sequence, I set the camera to a tripod taking 20-second shots continuously.

“I ended up with approximately 90 lightning shots, but had to exclude around 20.

“I believe the total number of strikes was more than 100.

“I have been doing landscape photography since 2006 and this is my lightning personal record. My previous best shot combined 42 shots.”

And Chris revealed that he didn’t even get wet capturing the spectacular light show.

He added: “This is not so dangerous as it seems. In fact when I was taking the shots, the storm was a few kilometers away.

“It wasn’t even raining where I was standing.”

pages.subdeck: Dispute ... petrol tanker drivers voted to strike
pages.headline: Fuel tanker driver talks under way
pages.teaser: TALKS aimed at resolving the fuel tanker drivers dispute and heading off any strike action got under way today
pages.articlebody:
TALKS aimed at resolving the fuel tanker drivers dispute and heading off any strike action got under way today.

Officials from the Unite union and seven distribution companies met in London under the chairmanship of the conciliation service Acas.

Briefings have been held with all the parties in the past few days and Acas said that “substantive conciliation talks” will take place today at an undisclosed location.

The dispute over terms and conditions and health and safety has been brewing for more than a year but flared up last week when Unite announced that workers in five of the firms had voted to strike.

The Government advised motorists to top up with fuel, leading to chaotic scenes at garages across the country as people queued for petrol.

Unite announced on Friday it would not be striking over Easter as it engaged with Acas over the peace moves, and would have to give seven days’ notice of any industrial action.

Unite general secretary Len McCluskey said: “For nearly two years, we have been trying to persuade the fuel distribution sector to work with us to defend best practice across the industry.

“It is vital that common, minimum standards on safety, training, wages and pensions are agreed to put a floor of best practice in the sector.”

A spokesman for Hoyer, one of the firms involved in the dispute, said: “Given that safety is a mantra for our business, we believe there are some fundamental areas of agreement between ourselves and Unite over the need to harmonise health and safety standards across the industry.”

pages.headline: Giant panters
pages.teaser: PANDAS filmed as they finally get in the mood for love
pages.articlebody:
BRITAIN’S giant pandas Sunshine and Sweetie were filmed as they finally got in the mood for love yesterday.

Their moves could go down even better than the notorious Tulisa Contostavlos sex tape.

But Sunshine will have to raise his game.

He mounted Sweetie five times as they met in the same cage for the first time — but failed to actually mate. Edinburgh Zoo, which hopes babies will result from the trysts, said: “Both seemed very keen and receptive.

"She was extremely interested and showing all the right signs. She was calling out to him in a high pitched sound.”

Keeper Alison Maclean, a vet, a zoologist and a Chinese panda expert watched anxiously as a “love tunnel” was opened, connecting adjoining cages in which the bears have lived for five months.

The zoo said: “Sweetie was rubbing against the sides of the love tunnel before it opened. As soon as they were introduced, they had a bit of ‘wrestling’.”

Staff separated the eight-year-olds when “the atmosphere changed” after a few minutes.

There are fears 14 stone Sweetie and 20 stone Sunshine could hurt each other in a tiff.

Their panda-cam was switched off during the sessions yesterday — but zoo bosses did make a “sex tape”.

Female pandas are fertile for only one 36-hour period each year. Another attempt at mating will be made today — and if that fails IVF will be tried next year. Even if Sweetie does get pregnant, experts won’t be able to tell for months.

pages.subdeck: Cat-astrophe ... Snowball poses a 'health and safety' risk, say Royal Mail
pages.headline: Letter at him!
pages.teaser: ROYAL Mail claim puss poses ‘unacceptably high level of risk’ after scratching postman
pages.articlebody:
PETRIFIED postmen are refusing to deliver mail to a house after being repeatedly attacked — by a tiny CAT.

Three-year-old Snowball stands just 10inchess tall and is described as “harmless and playful” by her owner Ian Wilkinson.

But Ian, 46, was shocked when he received a letter from Royal Mail informing him that his beloved pet was a “health and safety” risk.

The letter came after a postie suffered scratches to his finger while delivering mail through the letterbox last week.

Royal Mail claimed Snowball posed an “unacceptably high level of risk” and was a “potential hazard” to posties.

The company said three postmen have been attacked after delivering to Ian’s home in Peterborough, Cambs, with one suffering “quite deep” cuts to a finger.

Royal Mail conducted a health and safety assessment following a complaint by the postie — and it decided that it was too risky to deliver any post to his home.

Officials say deliveries will be suspended until Ian finds a way to ensure Snowball cannot get to any other delivery officers, or an “alternative safe delivery point” is put in place.

Divorced dad-of-one Ian, a computer analyst, said: “It’s utterly ridiculous.

“Everyone at work thinks it is hilarious — they have started calling her Ninja Cat and even Photoshopped her holding a Kalashnikov.

“I have never seen her attack a person.

“Sometimes she sniffs people’s feet when they come over for dinner - that’s as vicious as she gets.

“She happily plays with the next door’s animals and she wouldn’t hurt a fly.

“It’s not like she is a huge great Alsatian or a Doberman — she’s just a sweet little cat who is just inquisitive and playful.

“She is absolutely harmless. It’s all a bit bizarre.”

Royal Mail have accused Snowball of negotiating her way past the letterbox’s two spring-loaded covers and double brush guard to get to the hapless postie’s hand.

Ian added: “You have to stretch to even get your hand through the letterbox. At worst, this is just a cat wanting to play with someone wiggling their fingers through it.

“Although I acknowledge that my cat is a very intelligent animal, she is not able to lift up a spring loaded flap; keep it open; push her paw through a double brush guard and maul an unsuspecting delivery person in the time it take to delivery of the letter.”

Ian, who has not had any post for the last week, has now put a cage around the letterbox and hopes this will be satisfactory to resume the service.

He said: “I respect postmen come out in all sorts of weather conditions but they are in serious danger of making the Post Office a laughing stock.

“This has just made me think: ‘What on earth is going on with this world?’

“I thought it was an early April Fool’s joke when I got the letter — I just can’t get my head around it at all.”

Ian originally received a letter on November 15 last year stating that Snowball was a “potential hazard”.

The letter stated: “Either ensure that your cat is kept away from the letterbox or provide an alternative safe delivery point.”

He wrote back to ask for clarification, but got no response until a letter was sent to him by Royal Mail delivery office manager Jamie Clarke last Thursday.

Mr Clarke wrote: “On 28/03/12 at 1430 hours... our delivery officer was trying to deliver a pack to you.

“When they opened the letterbox your cat clawed out via the letterbox and cut our delivery officers finger quite deep.

“This is the third such incident. As a result it has been found that the level of risk is unacceptably high.”

Ian says he does not know the details of when the other two incidents took place.

A Royal Mail spokeswoman also could not confirm when the other two attacks were, as the sorting office had closed for the day.

She said: “There are around 4,000 animal attacks a year on Royal Mail people. These attacks cause great distress and in too many cases serious injuries.

“If we feel that there is a risk from any animal we are committed to working with the customer to agree simple steps to ensure that we can deliver the mail safely.”

But Neighbour Glenys Armstrong, 54, said: “Snowball is a lovely cat and friendly. I can’t imagine her ever attacking anybody.”

pages.headline: Bus-t not good enough
pages.teaser: DANIEL, 23, takes four hours to get just six miles - as buses won't stop for his wheelchair
pages.articlebody:
A WHEELCHAIR-bound man has told how he is constantly passed by as he waits for a bus — because drivers are banned from helping him on.

Daniel Brabazon often spends FOUR HOURS commuting to and from his work just six miles from his home.

The 23-year-old — who was paralysed from the waist down when he broke his spine in 2010 — is now demanding disabled access is improved in his home town of Plymouth.

He fumed: “This situation is ridiculous. A simple daily activity like catching a bus has been made so stressful."

Daniel claims he is constantly overlooked as he waits for buses in the city centre to take him the short distance to the B&Q where he works.

He claims the buses rarely boast a wheelchair ramp — and drivers are not allowed to help users board.

Daniel added: “The drivers are not always polite about not letting me on — it can be quite demeaning. Sometimes it’s just a shrug of the shoulders.

“They can make you feel really inadequate.”

Daniel returned to work in March, following months in hospital. But he claims that he can be forced to wait in the cold and rain for hours until a "low rider" vehicle, designed to lower to kerb height so wheelchair users can roll on and off, arrives.

But even then some curbs in the city are not raised, meaning the height difference is still too big for him to get on the bus.

Daniel, who is now learning to drive, added: “Where is the logic in having disabled space if a disabled person can’t get on?

“The situation has driven me crazy. I’ve had a tragic accident and all I want to do is go to work and go about my daily life.

“Never have I felt so bad for being disabled.”

Plymouth Citybus said it was accelerating its programme to make all buses wheelchair-friendly by 2015.

They say ten new vehicles, costing £1.6million, went into service this week as older models are phased out.

Citybus’s acting general manager Peter Oliver said around 75 per cent of buses were fitted with ramps.

But he added: “Users of local bus services must be able to board and alight bus services unaided.”

pages.subdeck: Suffering ... Sambuca the bull terrier
pages.headline: Dog so flea-ridden he bit off own tail
pages.teaser: VETS say the bull terrier chewed off part of its tail to get relief from scratching it
pages.articlebody:
A WOMAN allowed her dog to become so flea-ridden he bit off the end of his own tail, a court heard yesterday.

Bull terrier Sambuca was covered in weeping sores from an untreated flea allergy — eventually becoming so desperate he chewed off part of his tail.

Vets said the pet had been scratching and biting his skin for a month and had five-day-old sores when they examined him.

Owner Shelley Blackwell, 29, claimed she had treated the animal with off-the-shelf products but said they did not work.

Blackwell, of Milton Keynes, Bucks, was found guilty of causing unnecessary suffering.

She was fined £1,000 by magistrates in the town and ordered to do 120 hours of community service.

She was also told to hand Sambuca over to the RSPCA and banned from keeping animals for three years.

RSPCA Inspector Sue Haywood said after the case: “Vets’ investigations said it would have taken a month to have got to the state the end of the tail was in.

“There was signs of trauma from the five-day-old sores that has led to the dog biting off the end.

“For the sake of spending £20 or £30 on proper flea treatment from the vet's, all this could have been avoided.

“You can see if a product is or is not working and we would advise pet owners to take a vet’s advice if unsure.

“This should be a warning to everybody who has dogs or cats.

“We were satisfied with the sentence she received.”

FURIOUS Boris Johnson squared up to Ken Livingstone yesterday and called him “a f***ing liar”.

The London mayor confronted his election rival in a lift minutes after Mr Livingstone accused him of avoiding income tax in a live radio debate.

Shaking with anger, Tory Mr Johnson went nose to nose with Labour’s Red Ken and let rip with his four-letter curse THREE times.

Sources said Mr Livingstone “grinned nervously” while Green mayoral candidate Jenny Jones backed into the corner of the lift.

Brian Paddick, the Lib Dem hopeful in next month’s poll, and James Rea, managing editor of the capital’s LBC radio station, also looked on as Mr Johnson flipped.

The lift was heading up to a photoshoot on LBC’s roof terrace. And when the doors opened the candidates SMILED for the cameras.

The row erupted after Mr Livingstone was slammed by a caller for using a totally legal loophole to avoid £50,000 in tax by using a private firm, Silveta Ltd, to channel his income.

He insisted Mr Johnson had “the same arrangements” for dealing with his media earnings by using a company called Finland Station.

The mayor, who earns £250,000 a year as a newspaper columnist, blasted the claim as an “absolute lie”. He said: “I have never used a company to minimise my tax.”

Sources said Mr Johnson was incensed Mr Livingstone made the accusation as he privately assured him it was not true weeks ago.

Last night the mayor released a letter from his accountant stating: “He is liable to income tax on the entirety of his income and has made all due payments.”

Mr Livingstone’s spokesman said: “Boris Johnson lost his temper because he lost the debate.”

pages.subdeck: The only way is up ... Marcus is ecstatic to land his dream job
pages.headline: Freerunner jumps at chance to work in US
pages.teaser: MARCUS, 17, wows talent spotters with YouTube video - and lands his dream job teaching stunts to kids
pages.articlebody:
A TEENAGER has bagged his dream job teaching stunts in America after he was spotted jumping over a ROOF.

Marcus Wilson, 17, spends eight hours a day climbing over buildings, leaping off ledges and even launching himself off the pier in his home town.

The World Freerunning and Parkour Federation spotted his talent after he posted a video of his antics on YouTube.

And he has now been asked to jet out to America to give youngsters lessons in his rooftop stunts.

Marcus, who has been risking life and limb for his love of Parkour for four years, told how freerunning bosses had been watching his progress online for two years.

Marcus, from Beccles, Suffolk, said: “It is a really fun sport, keeps you fit and you meet lots of people through it.

“It feels amazing to jump over buildings.

“My parents have got used to it — they just like me to be careful.

“I will only do the jumps if I am in the right frame of mind. It is a mental thing as well. I wouldn’t do them if I was tired or feeling ill.

“We started filming for fun, but as we went on it we took it more and more seriously.

“I would love to make a living out of Parkour — it would be a fun job.”

pages.subdeck: What a difference a week makes ... snow has replaced last week's sunny weather
pages.headline: Snow falls a week after record heatwave
pages.teaser: PARTS of Britain woke up to snow today as last week's scorching weather is replaced by wintry sub-zero temperatures
pages.articlebody:
PARTS of Britain woke up to a blanket of snow yesterday as the recent scorching weather was replaced by wintry conditions and predictions of sub-zero temperatures.

Around seven inches of snow fell in Aviemore in the Highlands as an Arctic weather front bore down on the UK.

And yesterday nine hillwalkers, including six teenagers had to be rescued after becoming stranded in the treacherous conditions.

A major rescue operation was launched after the party became stuck in the Cairngorms.

Around four hours after they were initially alerted, police confirmed that the entire group had been rescued successfully.

The wintry blast comes just a week after record-breaking warm temperatures in north-eastern Scotland.

Last Tuesday temperatures rose to 23.6C in Aboyne, Aberdeenshire, marking a new high in Scotland for the month.

Yesterday the mercury dropped to minus 0.5C overnight and was at 0C at 6am.

The Met Office issued severe weather warnings for all of Scotland, as well as parts of northern England, Yorkshire and Humber, and the East Midlands.

The snow caused widespread travel chaos as temperatures plunged. Emergency services attend a seven-vehicle accident in Shotts, North Lanarkshire.

There were a number of other collisions and reports of cars sliding off the road in Tayside and Fife where some vehicles also became stuck in the snow in the Largoward and St Monans area.

Roads were closed in some areas due to the weather.

Around four inches (10cm) of snow carpeted most parts of northern Scotland, with 7.5 inches (17cm) recorded in Aviemore and temperatures of minus 2.7C in Glen Ogle.

Scotland’s central belt was also hit by the wintry weather, which will gradually creep into northern England, parts of Wales and the Midlands in the coming 24 hours.

Scottish Transport Minister Keith Brown said: “This kind of weather is much more normal for Scotland than the superb weather we have had over the previous days. So we have had, for example, 124 gritters out overnight.

“Because we’ve not had this kind of weather over previous weeks, it can catch people by surprise and what we’re saying is people should listen to the media, take on board any information they’ve got about the likely length of time to make their journeys and take the appropriate precautions.”

Forecasters predict that the snow will move south.

The weather is in stark contrast to March’s hot weather: the only years to have had a warmer month in the past 100 years are 1938, 1948, 1957, 1990 and 1997.

CURVY Kim Kardashian glows with optimism — as she declares the future is bright.

Kim, 32, said: “I’ve got a feeling this is going to be a good year for me — I’m putting the past behind me and have never felt more confident about my future.”

While she still believes in love, she no longer believes in “the one” and isn’t close to dating again. She said: “I’m just going to work on me for a bit.

“I think you have different soulmates throughout your life; that your soul needs different things at different times.

"I’m sure my soul will meet a mate one day in the future. I do believe in love, I will always believe in love, but my idea has changed from what I’ve always thought. I just don’t believe in one soulmate now.”

Discussing her life lessons, she says that she would like to become more private.

Talking about her family and herself, she said: “We know that we put ourselves in the public eye.

"We love doing our reality show, and it’s opened doors for us to have clothing lines and to do things we’ve always dreamt of. So it comes with the territory and we know that.

"But as I get older and go through certain things, it’s made me want to be more of a private person.

“I don’t think I would stop doing the reality show — I love doing it — but I wouldn’t have another relationship shown on the show.

"That might be too personal, especially when you’re just meeting someone. It’s taught me to be more private.”

Despite these stunning pictures Kim admits she still suffers from body blues.

The curvy beauty, who features in advertising campaigns for the Kardashians’ swimwear and underwear collection, told Cosmopolitan mag: “I didn’t always have a lot of confidence – especially not early on.

"But as I’ve got older, my confidence has grown and I like the person I am today because of that. I get a lot of my confidence from my sisters.

“If I don’t feel confident about my body, I’m not going to sit at home and feel sorry for myself and not do something about it.

"It’s all about taking action and not being lazy. So you do the work, whether it’s fitness or whatever. It’s about getting up, motivating yourself and just doing it.”

In a bid to boost her confidence Kim reveals she even tried her hand at singing: “I recorded a song once — I know I’m not a singer, and I don’t ever want to sing again!

“But I wanted to do something I was insecure about. It wasn’t for me, but it’s things like that where you have to push yourself and you become more sure of yourself.”

Ryan had moved the audience to tears as he sparked a guessing game over who the romantic ballad was for.

But she has told mutual pals: “We’re just friends.”

Ryan, also 19, had hoped his gamble to serenade Katie in front of millions on national TV would win her heart.

He even planned to whisk her away on holiday if he won the talent competition.

But in a crushing blow we can now reveal she fancies another pal. A source close to the pair, who did not want to be named, said last night: “I’m afraid it might be too late for Ryan.

“He’s a great guy but Katie has got the pick of the men.

“They are really good friends and have been for ages but that’s as far as it goes.

“There is someone else she is keen on. I suppose she could change her mind and if he goes all the way in the competition, who knows.”

Ryan met Katie at Portmarnock Community College in Dublin and they became good mates.

The pair even went to their school prom together last September.

Ryan had harboured a secret crush on Katie all these years but never found a way of telling her until his audition on the smash show last Saturday.

The emotional performance had the audience sighing and crying and won him a string of yes votes from the judges at the Blackpool audition.

Simon Cowell asked: “So that’s the first time she’s ever going to hear it? Wow. Well if that doesn’t work, nothing will.”

Recalling their school prom date, Ryan told The Sun: “When I saw her in that dress, I thought she looked beautiful.

“She makes me nervous. I don’t want to rush in. She’s my mate, she’s a nice girl and she has a beautiful smile.

“If I win I’ll spend my £500,000 on a holiday for just the two of us and maybe a sparkly ring if she’s lucky.”

But Ryan’s dad last night put paid to any hopes of a fairytale romance blossoming from his stunt.

Speaking from the family home in Loughshinny, Co Dublin, Brian said: “I don’t think there’s any chance of them getting together.

“They’re just friends, they’ve been friends for ages.

“He’s very fond of her. They’ve been mates since school.

“Ryan wanted to tell her something and did it on national telly.

“They are not an item and never have been. It’s not going to happen, unfortunately.”

Brian added: “It’s gone massive, this, and we’re all very surprised.”

Ryan’s future on BGT is under threat because earlier this year he appeared on the Irish version of The Voice. He signed a contract with Universal Music and is now begging bosses to free him, hoping public support will win them over.

He said: “On Britain's Got Talent I came across much better. If I could sing in the finals it would mean the world.”

Dressed in more stonewashed denim and studded leather than Bros had in their 1980s wardrobe, she actually had a song sheet in front of her for the more obscure tunes.

Tears On My Pillow also made an appearance for any Neighbours-era fans in the audience.

Charlene Mitchell would have been front row for a gig like that.

ONE Direction are already making Christmas plans — the boy band has booked a headlining gig at New York City's Madison Square Garden in December.

The British and Irish boys have taken the US by storm, scoring a number one with their debut album Up All Night.

And while they have been touring the country in support of Big Time Rush, they will return in December for their biggest concert to date at the 20,000 seater arena.

Tickets will go on sale on Friday and are expected to sell out in minutes.

Niall Horan said: "To be headlining our own show in a venue that has played host to countless legendary acts that we have grown up listening to and adore is obviously a dream come true for us all."

The group — which also includes Zayn Malik, Liam Payne, Harry Styles and Louis Tomlinson — formed in 2010 on the X Factor, but has since become a huge hit around the world.

Friday's ticket rush will kickstart an exciting weekend for One Direction fans — the band will appear on a new episode of hit kids show iCarly on Saturday, hours before making their debut on comedy show Saturday Night Live.

The band were also honoured with an invite to the White House by US first lady Michelle Obama for the Easter weekend after an appearance at the Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards in Los Angeles on Saturday.

However, they had to decline the offer as they will be in Australia.

When it was announced the band's album had gone to number one, Niall admitted he made a cab driver in New York jump with his excitement.

He said: "I was just screaming down the phone and frightened the life out of the cab driver!

"I had to explain the situation, because he looked at me like, 'Get out of my cab!' But I was shocked and shaking."

pages.headline: Lily Collins in Mirror Mirror
pages.teaser: ACTRESS on finally emerging from rock star dad’s shadow
pages.articlebody:
ACTRESS Lily Collins has finally emerged from the shadow of rock star dad Phil – and it’s all thanks to Snow White.

The 23-year-old former model is really getting noticed as the fairytale heroine playing opposite Julia Roberts as the Queen in new comedy fantasy film Mirror Mirror.

She was also the romantic lead to Twilight star Taylor Lautner in the 2011 thriller Abduction and has now signed to turn a hit young adult novel called The Mortal Instruments into a movie.

It is yet to be seen whether those projects put her in the same fame league as Dad, who has sold more than 250 million records. But Lily is certainly more youthful and current.

Speaking exclusively to The Sun, she says: “Someone told me they were listening to the radio and they were playing classic hits. At the end the DJ came on and said, ‘For all of you who don’t know, that was Phil Collins — Lily Collins’s dad’.

“I thought that was the weirdest thing, just so bizarre. Even my dad has said to me, ‘You know, I am known as your dad now’.

“But he is extremely proud and couldn’t be happier. He came to the premiere the other day and we were just like a huge family. It was so lovely to have Mum and Dad there.

“It is a weird shift. I am doing what I am now because I am doing it — I never wanted to give anybody the ability to say I am doing something because of family.”

Understandably, Lily is worried people will think having a famous father opened doors for her in the movie industry, giving her an unfair advantage. But there are plenty of sons and daughters of rock stars who have tried and failed to make it in Hollywood.

Phil, 61, who was an actor before he became a rock star with Genesis, has commented about how difficult Lily’s family background has made it for her. He once said: “She’s always got this thing hanging around her neck — she’s Phil Collins’s daughter.”

Lily thinks Dad was just defending her and says: “He is probably just referencing what everyone assumes — that having the last name gives me an opportunity and protecting me from that.”

Whether being Phil’s daughter has helped or hindered, Lily certainly didn’t get her stunning looks from Dad. For those remarkable eyes she has mum Jill Tavelman to thank.

Lily says: “I have seen that more and more. I am seeing characteristics, things that I do that are very her. And I look at photos sometimes and see her smile and her laugh. More and more people are saying that now — and I love it.”

Jill was Phil’s second wife. They married in 1984 and divorced 12 years later. After the break-up, Lily, then seven, went to live with her mother in Los Angeles.

The split was said to be acrimonious, with Phil paying out £17million and finishing the relationship by fax. But now it seems they are friendly again.

Lily, whose birthday was on March 18, says: “I celebrated my 23rd with my mum and dad, who were both here in LA the day after the premiere. We had a very relaxed, quiet day together.”

Although she mainly grew up in the States, Surrey-born Lily has fond memories of an English childhood spent in the company of some of the UK’s biggest stars — including Elton John, who used to babysit her.

She says: “He is definitely a close family friend. I consider myself very European and more British at heart.

“I am not your beachy Californian girl. I enjoy the cold. Whenever I come back to England I automatically relax and feel at home.”

Lily reckons spending her early years in England helped to prepare her for the Snow White role.

She says: “I grew up in England in the countryside in basically farmland and forests.

“I used to run around pretending. I was read fairytales before bedtime and I was totally the young girl who loved fairytale princesses.

“The idea of playing one never crossed my mind and when it happened, at first I thought it was a mistake. But it was an absolute honour and I was so excited to do it that the importance of playing this iconic role didn’t truly hit home until I finished shooting, so I didn’t get to be nervous about it.”

She adds: “To play a character that is the fairest of them all is even hard for me to say — it is the most bizarre concept to me.

“In our story Snow White never once looks in the mirror, so she is unaware of the beauty everyone is talking about. She doesn’t know what effect it has on people.”

And Lily too is confused by the effect she is having on people, with fan sites dedicated to her already springing up.

She says: “It still shocks me that people are interested in me.

“But I can still go about everyday life, go to the market and that kind of thing, without being followed.”

Lily’s first acting role came at the tender age of TWO on BBC television comedy drama Growing Pains.

Before her adult acting career she worked as a journalist for American youth channel Nickleodeon and for British teen magazines such as Elle Girl. She admits it was a way to get experience in front of the camera and a job to do as she waited for her big chance in Hollywood.

The break came when she played the daughter of Sandra Bullock’s character in the Oscar-nominated 2009 film The Blind Side. After that success she decided to concentrate on acting.

Talking about her time as a reporter, she says: “I was always pursuing acting at the same time. I was just auditioning but being told no and so I kept practising. At the same time I wanted to be doing something else. Then I was finally told yes on The Blind Side and there came a point when I had to decide whether the audience could believe me as the character when I was also on television as me.”

Dad Phil started acting young, having gone to drama school at 14 and appearing as the Artful Dodger in a London production of Oliver!

Lily says: “I have always loved dressing up. I was also supported by my family. Me and my dad obviously share a love of acting.”

And they are far from being the only star dad-and-daughter acting team — as our picture gallery, below left, shows.

This new version of Snow White portrays the princess as a strong young woman who is as brave as her prince.

Lily says: “I wanted to play her as a young girl that other young girls could relate to.

“I got to do all these things I have never done before, like fencing and running round in ball gowns and corsets in forests.”

For Lily, there is a similarity between herself and this modern princess. She is not the type of girl who simply lives off her parent’s fame but wants to make her own way in the world.

She says: “She’s a feisty, passionate young woman. I’d definitely say that when I set my mind on something, I really go for it.”

pages.headline: Will he let you stay friends with an ex?
pages.teaser: AS celebrities like Kelly and Angelina count exes amongst their pals, two women share their very different experiences
pages.articlebody:
WHEN relationships come to an end, most couples part company for good.

But an increasing number of celebrities are now choosing to stay friends with their ex.

Last month, Angelina Jolie wrote the foreword to former hubby Billy Bob Thornton’s book and the two Hollywood stars have remained close.

Model Kelly Brook has stayed in touch with previous boyfriends, rugby ace Danny Cipriani and film star Jason Statham. And actress Courteney Cox still calls former husband David Arquette her “favourite person in the world”. But while these celebs insist being friends with a former lover is healthy, can it work for us mere mortals?

Here, JENNY FRANCIS meets two women with very different views about staying bosom buddies with the ex- lover.

YES, says Lucy O'Connor, 22

WAITRESS Lucy sees her former boyfriend Dom Mitchison, 26, a music student at least once a week. She has now been with Dave Norman, 28, a tiler, for 18 months and says she wouldn’t be happy in any relationship where she is not allowed to see her ex. They are all from Bristol. Lucy says:

“I met Dom in September 2008. We were both students and I fell for him because he was so easy to talk to.

We became great friends first, then evolved into boyfriend and girlfriend.

We moved in together after a year and all was going well until our mutual friend blurted out she had slept with Dom.

I was utterly crushed and my trust of Dom evaporated.

Despite my anger at him breaking us up, Dom and I would bump into each other at university, we had the same mutual friends and I found it impossible to ignore him.

Gradually we became friends again.

We shared so much together in such an exciting period of our lives and that bond couldn’t be broken.

We talk about everything together and he’s a great listener.

But I’d never trust him as a boyfriend again.

I met Dave a year after splitting from Dom and we hit it off.

Dave knows all about what happened between me and Dom. At first he couldn’t understand why I’d want to be friends with him.

But he soon came to understand how supportive Dom had been as a friend — and still is.

So far it’s working out nicely.

The boys get on fine when we meet up together but I’m not sure if they would be friends in their own right.

Dom and I meet up for coffees or early-evening drinks at least once a week.

I don’t discuss relationship problems with him though, I have girlfriends for that.

I feel lucky that I have a boyfriend who understands. If he didn’t, things could get complicated.”

Boyfriend Dave says: “I’m cool with Lucy’s friendship with Dom.

“Dom and I are completely different — I wouldn’t go out drinking with him.

“But he’s funny and I have to respect him because Lucy does.”

Ex Dom says: “To throw away the bond Lucy and I formed would be impossible.

“I know I screwed up but it was completely out of character and I’m very lucky to still have Lucy as a friend.

“I’ve got friends who can’t be friends with their exes so I see myself as fortunate to have Lucy in my life still.

“I really think we’ll be in touch for many years.”

NO, says Suzanne Parker, 36

SUZANNE, who runs a menswear shop in Ormskirk, Lancs, was given an ultimatum: Stay friends with her ex and lose her boyfriend. She says:

“I’d known my ex, Martin, since I was five and we’d always been good friends.

Three years ago we began dating, which turned out to be a big mistake.

What was a friendship soon turned into bickering.

After five months we realised we weren’t suited to one another and split.

At first it was a bit strange between us but once we got over the awkwardness of knowing we’d slept together, we fell back into being friends.

Two months after we split I began dating Adam, who I met through Facebook.

Adam was lovely and we seemed made for each other.

I told Martin about Adam from the start.

He was very excited that I was starting to see someone new.

The two of them met about a month after Adam and I started dating.

They got on like a house on fire and we would often hang out together.

Despite seeing how well they got on, I decided not to tell Adam that Martin and I had been an item.

But two years into our relationship, I was chatting with Adam about my past and casually mentioned I’d dated Martin.

As I told him I could see him become tense and within minutes he was furious.

I tried to convince him nothing would ever go on between us, but he wouldn’t have it.

He gave me an ultimatum — either stop talking to Martin or our relationship was over.

I couldn’t believe it. I was hurt and shocked by his reaction. I told him he couldn’t control me and my friendships.

But he remained adamant it was Martin or him.

I was torn.

I didn’t want to sacrifice a friendship over somebody’s jealousy, but I’d really fallen for Adam and didn’t want to throw away what we had.

For the next month I carried on phoning Martin and each time Adam found out he went ballistic. We had the most awful rows.

Eventually Adam moved out.

I really missed him and phoned to ask him to come home, but he told me that he only would if I stopped talking to my ex, Martin.

I didn’t want to choose.

I was terribly upset that it ended the way it did, but maybe this proves it wasn’t meant to be between us.”

Security worker Adam Smith, 32, says: “I didn’t like the idea of ex-boyfriends being in the background — it felt like an intrusion.

“Suzanne wouldn’t have it though and it was stressing me out so I left.

“It’s over now and it’s all because she wanted to stay friends with her ex.”

Martin Hollenby, 33, a woodworker, says: “It’s sad what happened, but I don’t see why Suzie and I couldn’t be friends.

“There was nothing going on between us. If Adam couldn’t accept that then it’s his problem.

“I thought he was all right — it seems I was wrong.”
