pages.subdeck: UNITED FRONT ... Ash & Co are top of the pile
pages.headline: We have no fear
pages.teaser: WINGER believes that City are already gripped by fear ahead of cross-town title showdown
pages.articlebody:
ASHLEY YOUNG believes that Manchester City are already gripped by fear as they await their title showdown with arch-rivals United.

England striker Young and United head across town to the Etihad on April 30 determined to avenge the 6-1 humiliation they suffered at Old Trafford in October last year.

Young, who scored the second in Monday’s crucial 2-0 win at Blackburn, insisted: “I think City are fearing our reaction already.

“A lot of people wrote us off earlier in the season with City being seven points clear.

“But we’ve just been going about our job quietly and now we’ve managed to claw it back.”

The Manchester derby was being billed as a possible title decider with the two teams neck and neck at the top.

But champions and current leaders United have pulled five points clear and the nightmare scenario now for City fans is that their neighbours clinch the title on the last day of this month.

Young and his team-mates are determined to ensure the game goes down in Manchester folklore just like October 23, 2011 did. He believes the champions have shown they have the bottle to go the distance while their neighbours have cracked under the heat.

He told Match of the Day magazine: “The pressure has always been on City — there aren’t any nerves coming from our side.

“We don’t play with fear and we haven’t got any nervousness going into games.

“We’ve got the momentum going into the final stretch of the season.”

By the time City play Arsenal on Sunday they could be eight points adrift of United, who have a lunchtime clash with QPR the same day.

Young added: “We have another massive game on Sunday and it’s not going to be easy. But we play before City and can put ourselves eight points clear of them which at this stage of the season is massive. Winning at Blackburn on Monday was a huge result. This is a crucial time of the season for us — everyone knows that.”

After a summer spending spree and with young players being blooded, this was always viewed as a season of transition for United.

But they look like ending it with a 20th top-flight crown and Young believes manager Alex Ferguson has got the blend just right.

He says the youngsters have learned a great deal from veterans Ryan Giggs, 38, and Paul Scholes, 37, who came out of retirement in January.

Both played key roles in the vital win over Blackburn and Young feels they still have plenty to offer.

He said: “The younger players have taken over this season, with their music and general loudness.

“But if someone like Ryan Giggs or Paul Scholes starts talking we all sit down and listen. I asked the boys about Scholesy as soon as I joined and they said he was unbelievable in training.

“He still pings the ball around like you wouldn’t believe.” Ferguson also believes the old heads have been the key to United’s season as they close in on yet another title.

He said: “It’s down to experience. It never fazes them and they can handle it. We’re doing okay right now.

“Scholes and Giggs are unparalleled of course but I think Rooney has four title medals, Rio five, Michael Carrick has got a few.

“Even people like Rafael has got two or three. So it all adds to the experience, and that’s valuable at this time of the season.”

Meanwhile, Sunderland pair Phil Bardsley and Lee Cattermole have told City: You’re not as good as you think you are.

The pair were not impressed by Roberto Mancini’s men as the Black Cats bagged a point in a 3-3 draw at the Etihad on Saturday.

Scotland international Bardsley believes all the hype surrounding City is way off the mark.

He said: “They weren’t the team that they’ve been made out to be. They weren’t that impressive.”

And Sunderland skipper Cattermole reckoned City were not up for the battle.

He insisted: “We took City apart on their own pitch. Once we got the ball down, I didn’t think they had the hunger to chase it down.”

pages.subdeck: YOU CESCY THING ... Fabregas hails Lionel Messi on his first penalty
pages.headline: Barcelona 3 AC Milan 1
pages.teaser: LIONEL MESSI rewrote the history books yet again as he set up a potential Euro semi-final clash with Chelsea
pages.articlebody:
(Barcelona win 3-1 on agg)

PEP GUARDIOLA cranked up the pressure on Chelsea after record-breaker Leo Messi led Barcelona to the Champions League semis.

Messi netted twice from the spot to reach a record 14 goals in UEFA’s elite competition.

And boss Guardiola turned the screw on Roberto Di Matteo’s Blues, insisting they will struggle to get past Benfica in their own quarter-final tonight.

Barca await the winners and Chelsea have the upper hand over the Portuguese outfit after their 1-0 win at the Estadio da Luz last week.

But Guardiola said: “Chelsea are not through yet. In the first game Benfica had many chances. They do have a great result winning 1-0 away but let’s wait until tomorrow night. Both teams would be difficult. We’re happy to be in the semi-finals for the fifth consecutive season.”

If Chelsea see off Benfica they will set up a repeat of their hugely controversial 2009 semi-final.

Back then, notorious ref Tom Henning Ovrebo caused a storm as he turned down four decent penalty shouts for the West Londoners before Andres Iniesta’s sensational last-minute strike saw the Catalan giants through on away goals.

The good news for Chelsea? Messi has never scored against them. The bad news? He will be desperate to change that stat in another record-breaking season.

There was some refereeing controversy last night too, though nowhere near the same scale as Ovrebo.

After 11 minutes, Dutch ref Bjorn Kuipers gave a stonewall penalty as Luca Antonini upended Messi. The Argentina ace put it away with ease. Barca dominated and wasted chances but Milan stuck at it and, as long as it stayed 1-0, they were in with a shout.

Antonio Nocerino’s 32nd-minute leveller was not in the script — but after the goalless first leg, his strike meant the Italians took the advantage by virtue of their away goal.

An upset looked on the cards — but four minutes before the interval Kuipers pointed to the spot again.

OK, it was a penalty by the letter of the law as Alessandro Nesta pulled Sergio Busquets as Isaac Cuenca whipped in a corner.

But the big question former Chelsea boss and chief Barca-basher Jose Mourinho is likely to ask this morning is simple: How many other teams would have been given a penalty in a similar situation? It was one of those that happens by the dozen in every high-level football match.

Messi struck the kick coolly into the opposite corner to his first to restore the lead.

And Milan boss Massimiliano Allegri said: “We gifted them the first penalty but with the second the ref gave them some help. The second penalty was awarded very easily.

“Without that, the game could have been made complicated for Barcelona.”

Guardiola hit back insisting the ref was right and pointed to Barcelona’s 21 shots.

The Barca boss said: “Both were penalties. I’ve seen them on TV. If there is a penalty, the ref must give it.

“We had 21 shots, against an Italian team of the quality of Milan — not three or four.”

Milan did not have a single shot in the second half. But the visitors DID have a valid penalty shout when Daniel Alves brought down Robinho.

Kuipers waved it away and, after 53 minutes, Iniesta added the killer blow — just as he did at Chelsea in 2009.

pages.subdeck: KENNY DO IT ... Dalglish is under huge pressure to sort out the shambles at Anfield
pages.headline: Embarrassing
pages.teaser: ANFIELD legend has launched an astonishing attack on his old club
pages.articlebody:
JOHN ALDRIDGE has launched an astonishing attack on Liverpool and dubbed his old club a ‘laughing stock’.

Local-boy Aldridge spent 2½ years with his boyhood heroes as part of a forward unit many Kopites still rate as the most breathtaking in the Reds’ history.

Few former stars have been hurt quite as much by the club’s worst run since 1953 and the prospect of their lowest-ever Premier League finish as Aldo.

Sunday’s 2-0 humiliation at Newcastle was their sixth loss in seven league games, and only rock-bottom Wolves have a poorer record since the turn of the year.

Most humiliating of all for die-hard Reds is the serious prospect of finishing below neighbours Everton for only the second time in Premier League history.

Now one-time Kop idol Aldo has aimed both barrels at his former employers — and delivered a verdict as deadly as the finishing which brought him 63 goals in 104 games.

Aldridge, who watches Liverpool every week working for local radio, blasted: “Liverpool are now in a crisis. To lose six out of seven in the league is something the club won’t tolerate, we can’t tolerate.

“To have picked up just eight points out of 36 since the turn of the year is shambolic — relegation form.

“The fact that this is the worst run in the league since 1953 speaks volumes. The eyes of the world are on Liverpool FC and the critics are having a field day. We’re becoming a laughing stock.

“We’re all proud to be associated with the club and everything it has achieved over the years. But at the moment being a fan is just embarrassing and that’s something I haven’t had to say before.”

Aldridge went to Anfield in 1987, snapped up from Oxford by current Kop boss Kenny Dalglish to replace Juventus-bound Ian Rush.

He spearheaded a line-up which included Peter Beardsley and John Barnes, and lifted two league titles and an FA Cup, before heading for Real Sociedad.

The Liverpool of today could hardly be more removed from the one of his day, which went on a then record unbeaten start of 29 games and lifted the title at a canter.

Aldridge, 53, said: “You can blame the manager and the coaching staff but it comes down to the players.

“Some of them should take a look in the mirror.They are playing for one of the biggest clubs in the world.

“We know we’re not the finished article but we’re better than what we’ve seen recently.

“The team just seems to have lost belief. They need to get back to playing for each other.

“We’ve talked about good performances not getting the rewards they deserved, but it’s time for all those excuses to be thrown out of the window.

“Liverpool FC fans are going to work distraught and seeing the team struggle like they did at Newcastle hurts a lot.”

The Reds have proved they can still match the big guns in a one-off — as they proved by knocking both Manchester clubs out of the domestic cups.

The Carling Cup is in safe keeping, and on Saturday week they have a Wembley showdown with Everton as they gun for a place in the FA Cup final.

But they will have to do it without keeper Pepe Reina, banned for three games after his dismissal at Newcastle, and with players’ confidence on the slide.

Aldo added: “When you are in a rut it’s hard to get out of it.

“As a manager sometimes you have to do something different just to try to get a response. When I was at Tranmere occasionally I’d take all the lads for a Chinese or a few beers.

“Something needs to be done to spark a reaction.

“More than anything I want to see some pride. That’s all we’re playing for in the league now.

“The target has to be to make sure the Blues don’t finish above us.

“They have turned their season around and now we need to see our players follow suit.”

“We feel the best thing is for the doctors to take another look and see if they can get to the root of the problem.

pages.headline: 2million Test runs
pages.teaser: A MAN of astonishing geekiness worked out that the 2,000,000th run was hit here
pages.articlebody:
A MAN of astonishing geekiness worked out that the 2,000,000th run in the history of Test cricket was scored yesterday.

And England’s weary bowlers must feel as though most of the two million have been made by Mahela Jayawardene after another day witnessing one of his masterclasses.

Sri Lanka’s magical little batsman almost exactly repeated his feat from the first day of the First Test eight days earlier.

Jayawardene once more walked to the wicket with James Anderson on a hat-trick, repelled a superb new-ball burst by the England paceman and then cruised and caressed his way to a wondrous century.

This was hi 31st in Test cricket and his eighth against England.

Jayawardene, 34, was finally out for 105 on the opening day of the Second Test as Sri Lanka finished with 238-6.

That represents a decent recovery by Sri Lanka after Anderson reduced them to 30-3 — although England’s discipline meant the home batsmen were never able to press the accelerator too firmly.

The two millionth run arrived in the 2,039th Test when Jayawardene (below) square cut a boundary off Anderson that advanced Sri Lanka’s total from 37 to 41.

Such revelations might have statisticians somewhere close to ecstasy but, for England’s bowlers, Jayawardene brought only toil and sweat.

So thank goodness for Anderson’s talent for the umpteenth time in the past few years.

He was magnificent with the new ball after Sri Lankan skipper Jayawardene won what looked like an important toss.

The 29-year-old Lancashire star removed three batsmen in his initial spell with a craftsman’s mixture of swing, seam and accuracy.

The frisky Tillakaratne Dilshan was lured into an edge and then Kumar Sangakkara nicked his first ball to slip, where Andrew Strauss snatched the catch at the second attempt.

For a man under pressure, Strauss’ relief at clinging on to the chance could be felt from 100 yards away.

Sangakkara, one of the world’s best batsmen, has been out for two golden ducks in three innings.

Curiously, the ball was changed immediately before the hat-trick delivery because it had gone out of shape.

All balls come the same to Jayawardene, though, and he glanced it for four. He was on his serene, almost stealthy way.

Anderson’s third wicket came when left-handed opener Lahiru Thirimanne padded up and was plumb lbw.

Steven Finn, playing instead of the injured Stuart Broad, was full of praise for his new-ball partner.

Finn, 23 today, said: “I’ve learned a lot from Jimmy, especially over the last 12 months.

“He is an exceptional fast bowler who knows how to extract the maximum movement, nip and swing in any conditions.

“To have him talking to me at mid-on or mid-off when I’m walking back to my mark and helping get my mind right is definitely a big help.

“As a young player, I can learn from him about taking wickets.

“He is so patient, he doesn’t go searching for those wickets. He is as consistent as possible.

“Jayawardene played very well and assessed the conditions excellently. But he didn’t take the game away from us, even though he scored a century.”

Jayawardene offered a half-chance to Alastair Cook at short leg off Graeme Swann on 34.

And, on 79, he edged Anderson between wicketkeeper Matt Prior and Strauss. Otherwise, his innings was error-free. In fact, he offered fewer chances than during his 180 in Galle, although he did not produce quite as much dazzling strokeplay.

In 11 home Tests against England, Jayawardene has scored six centuries and averages 90.66.

They are remarkable figures.

Jayawardene put on 124 for the fourth wicket in 44 overs with Thilan Samaraweera, who accumulated in his own unhurried way — although he was shaken up when struck on the helmet by Finn.

Samaraweera also survived a DRS verdict by third umpire Rod Tucker, even though England’s fielders believed he should have been given out caught by Cook at short leg off Finn. Samaraweera was leg before to Tim Bresnan — chosen ahead of Monty Panesar — and Jayawardene was finally out lbw to Swann.

He reviewed the decision but the replay showed sharp turn for Swann from around the wicket and umpire Asad Rauf’s verdict was vindicated.

England collected one more wicket before the close when Finn coaxed an edge from Sri Lankan wicketkeeper Prasanna Jayawardene to Prior.

Samaraweera said: “Mahela is very calm. We have played a lot of cricket together and I can tell he is in tremendous form.

“He is a great player and gave good advice to me.”

pages.headline: Things didn't go quite to plan
pages.teaser: ROB HUFF looks back on his failed bid to make April fools of my rivals at Valencia last Sunday
pages.articlebody:
I TOLD you in my last column I would aim to make April fools of my rivals at Valencia last Sunday.

Unfortunately, it turned out the joke was on me as nearly all of them raised their game!

Perhaps they read what I had to say and thought they would teach cocky Huffy a lesson and spank his bottom.

Such is the power of The Sun, I guess, and it has spread all around the world now thanks to the digital age so everyone sees it.

It’s not that I had a BAD weekend in the World Touring Car Championship’s second round.

I’m still a reasonably close fourth in the standings with tons of points still on offer, it’s just that the series this year is so darn competitive that a truck-load of drivers are capable of taking the chequered flag.

Including, of course, my Chevrolet Cruze team-mates Yvan Muller and Alain Menu, who proved it by taking a win apiece.

Valencia is a track I enjoy and the weather in Spain is always great, but the event got off to a slow start for me.

Normally I fly out to a race weekend on the Thursday, but there was a strike on that day across the whole of Spain, which forced me to arrive on the Friday.

I went straight to the track after landing to get a feel for it ahead of the practice sessions first thing on Saturday morning.

My pace in practice was excellent and the Cruze showed what it was capable of as I went second fastest in both sessions.

Qualifying was a tougher prospect but I made it through to Q2 without any problems. A time of 1:42.862 put me fifth on the grid for Race one.

And I got off to a great start, passing Spanish youngster Pepe Oriola on the opening lap to take fourth.

It was a really tightly contested race. I had one eye on Tom Coronel’s BMW ahead but was also very wary of my charging team-mate Alain behind.

I ended up finishing fourth, by no means a bad result, with Alain 0.268s back.

Race two was just as close, Russian racer Aleksei Dudukalo stalled from third on the grid and a bunch of us had to take evasive action.

In the aftermath I was down to sixth and again in the middle of a bumper-to-bumper bunch.

I had to watch out for Yvan behind me. He’s always a tough nut to crack and is not the reigning WTCC champion for nothing, but I held him off and took sixth at the flag.

Obviously the start to this year has not been as strong as my form in the first two race weekends last year, when I won twice.

But that just goes to show what I mean about the tough nature of this year’s series.

On a positive note, my run of consecutive points finishes now stands at 35. I’ve also finished my last 46 races, stretching back almost two years.

The next race weekend in Marrakech is firmly on my radar for my first win of 2012. I’m in no doubt it’ll be just as tough out there and maybe some drivers will go loco in Morocco.

But if I stay out of trouble, I’m hoping to tell you about a triumph or two next time around.

Talk to you then.
